t: Ecclesiastes 5
Fear God, Keep Your Vows
Walk*p prudently when you go to the house of God; and draw near to hear rather than to give the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they do evil.
Do*pn not be rash with your mouth, And*ld let not your heart utter anything hastily before God. For*ld God is*i in heaven, and you on earth; Therefore*ld let your words be few.
For*ld a dream comes through much activity, And*ld a fool’s voice is*i known*i by his*i many words.
When*ln you make a vow to God, do not delay to pay it; For*ld He*i has*i no pleasure in fools. Pay*ld what you have vowed—
Better*ld not to vow than to vow and not pay.
Do*p not let your mouth cause your flesh to sin, nor say before the messenger of*i God*i that it was*i an error. Why should God be angry at your excuse and destroy the work of your hands?
For in the multitude of dreams and many words there*i is*i also vanity. But fear God.
The Vanity of Gain and Honor

If*p you see the oppression of the poor, and the violent perversion of justice and righteousness in a province, do not marvel at the matter; for high official watches over high official, and higher officials are over them.
Moreover*p the profit of the land is for all; even*i the king is served from the field.
He*pn who loves silver will not be satisfied with silver; Nor*ld he who loves abundance, with increase. This*ld also is*i vanity.
When*ln goods increase, They*ld increase who eat them; So*ld what profit have the owners Except*ld to see them*i with their eyes?
The*ln sleep of a laboring man is*i sweet, Whether*ld he eats little or much; But*ld the abundance of the rich will not permit him to sleep.
There*ln is a severe evil which*i I have seen under the sun: Riches*ld kept for their owner to his hurt.
But*ld those riches perish through misfortune; When*ld he begets a son, there*i is*i nothing in his hand.
As*ld he came from his mother’s womb, naked shall he return, To*ld go as he came; And*ld he shall take nothing from his labor Which*ld he may carry away in his hand.
And*ln this also is*i a severe evil— Just*ld exactly as he came, so shall he go. And*ld what profit has he who has labored for the wind?
All*ld his days he also eats in darkness, And*ld he*i has*i much sorrow and sickness and anger.

Here*p is what I have seen: It*i is*i good and fitting for*i one*i to eat and drink, and to enjoy the good of all his labor in which he toils under the sun all the days of his life which God gives him; for it is*i his heritage.
As for every man to whom God has given riches and wealth, and given him power to eat of it, to receive his heritage and rejoice in his labor—this is*i the gift of God.
For he will not dwell unduly on the days of his life, because God keeps him*i busy with the joy of his heart.
